sourceDesc.p: The original source for this dataset is a database dump by the Bodleian Libraries at .

org.note: Importer of foreign music and map seller. Sold publications issued by John Welcker
Agent. Trading as Vacher & Davies 1807-27; Vacher & Sons 1839

address.addrLine: Cock and Sugar Loaf, Fleet St
Strand (opposite the French church of the Savoy)

org.note: Originally bookseller to Academie de Saumur. Left France 1685
Part bro Paul Vaillant I. Succeeded by nephew Paul Vaillant II 1750
Son of FRANCOIS VAILLANT. Dates suggest a possible conflation of PAUL VAILLANT I & II

address.addrLine: O/a Bedford Hse in the Strand

org.note: Part Isaac Vaillant. Succeeded by Paul Vaillant II (Isaac's nephew)

address.addrLine: Strand. Opp Southampton St, Strand. 87 Strand. Pall Mall

org.note: Son of Paul Vaillant I. Successor to uncle Isaac Vaillant. Apprenticed to cousin Nicholas Prevost 1730; FSC & LivSC 1738; MSC 1770. A Huguenot. Sheriff of London.
Son of Jabez Vale. See J Vale & Son, Liverpool
Father of Edwin Vale. See J Vale & Son, Liverpool
Probably same as or related to Thomas James Vale.

address.addrLine: Suffolk St. 2 Church St. 29/41/113 Moor St. 29 Cannon St. 3-4 Weaman St. 3/7 Freeman St.

org.note: Part Thomas Simms (diss 17/5/1824); possibly part J Baldwin (1830-48). Probably same as or related to Thomas Vale. 1847 directory index has 'Vale, J.'

address.addrLine: Eign St (1826). 23 High Town (1828-50). Journal Office Broad St (1850)

org.note: Acquired `Hereford Journal' from Edward Weymss 1850. Succeeded by William Phillips 1856. Master of William Phillips
Also in London (Little Britain, London in 1830). Also Baldwin & Vale. Probably Thomas James Vale & James Baldwin. Possibly successors to Vale & Simms
Also in Birmingham (1827-30). Also Baldwin & Vale. Probably James Baldwin & Thomas James Vale
Part Thomas James Vale & Thomas Simms: diss 17/5/1824 notice: `London Gazette' 3/7/1824

address.addrLine: At the Queen's Hd ag St Dunstan's Church, Fleet St

org.note: Book printed for and sold by [1764?].
and broker (?) From a family of musicians etc.
Mill formerly held by William Vallance. Paid excise duties at Uxbridge Collection in 1816

At Hatfield Mill. Possibly at Wheathampstead. Advertised writing, wrapping & printing paper of own manufacture 1781. Trading as Vallance & Simmons; Vallance & Condor; Vallance & Son. Succeeded by Edmund Vallance
At London. Mill insured by R Lyon & A Lambert of Carshalton in 1782 (SFIP 469042). Var ins: R 101612 (1785/7), R 92404 (1785/6). Employees tried for 'conspiracy to raise wages' in 1790: T Arnold &c
Mill held by Francis Owen in 1781 (NB F Owen possibly also at Pickford Mill, later held by William & E Vallance). Probably the same as T Vallance at Hatfield. [Ins pol: R 99051 (1786/7)]
Possibly the same as William Vallance ST &c, Harpenden. Mill formerly held by Francis Owen. Insured paper mill in 1813 (SFIP 880275). Mill passed to Edmund Vallance by 1816
ironmonger. Possibly the same as William Vallance PP, Pickford Mill
Apprenticed to James & William Simmonds. Fellow apprentice was Thomas Eede

address.addrLine: 21 Tooke's Ct, Chancery La. 4 Red Lion Ct, Fleet St. 4 Redlion Passage (1839)
8 Pear Tree St, Goswell St (1805). 236 Tooley St. 17/18 Tooley St

org.note: Listed as steel pen & fluid maker
He accuses James Van Nethe of leaving his service before the term agreed
Accused of leaving service of Roland Van Let a peyntour before term agreed

address.addrLine: Sign of Virgill's [sic] Head, opposite Exeter Exchange in the Strand

org.note: Part J Groenegen 1721-7; I Vandenhoeck 1732; G Richmond (Strand). Succeeded by J Wilcox (1734)
Possibly related to Abraham Vandenhoeck. Trading as A & I Vandenhoeck (1732)

address.addrLine: Great Brooke St, Grosvenor Sq (1763). Lower Brooke St (1774-6)

org.note: berlin & general repository. Earlier in London
Also Vanderbank etc. Born Paris. Pupil of Poilly. Died Cottered, Hertfordshire
Possibly the same as Stephen Bukbynder
Will dated 29/6/1575 proved at York vol 19/887
Probably related to William Henry Varden (same address)
Probably related to James Varden (same address)
inspector of corn returns. Probably related to Richard Vardy (same address)
ins (Phoenix & Pelican). Probably related to Joshua Lambert Vardy (same address)

address.addrLine: At Seneca's Head, near Somerset House in the Strand

org.note: Possibly related to P de Varenne (1695-1724); Varens (1711)

address.addrLine: At the Seneca's Head, near Somerset House in the Strand

org.note: Possibly related to Matthew de Varenne (1723-4); Varens (1711)
Off French extraction. Also known as P de Varenne.

address.addrLine: At Seneca's Head, near Exeter-Change in the Strand

org.note: Probably the same as PIEERE DE VARENNES 1 and/or II.

address.addrLine: Seneca's Head, near Somerset House in the Strand

org.note: Possibly related to M de Varenne or P de Varenne (same address)
master of John Hedley 1713. master of Milford Flower 1720

address.addrLine: 3 Red Lion St, St Ann's (1822-28); Hse: 63 St George's Rd (1824) Cumberland St (1816)
At the Oxford Arms in Lombard St

org.note: Also Vernon & Osborne. See Thomas Varnam (Vernon?) & John Osborn

address.addrLine: 3 redlion st, 8 bury st, chorlton upon medlock

org.note: Part Henry Winchester; trading as Winchester & Varnham (1819-33)
Son of John Vasey of Southwark, carpenter. Succeeded by widow, Mary Vasey
Also known as Hermitage Mill. See Francis Chapman, William Ward, Francis Ward, John Ward

Also known as VAUS or VANCE. Maker's marks: Crispin and Crispiana, The Royal Arms, The Royal Pearl, The Great Mogul (all 1707); The Highlander (1709); The Duke of Argyll (1711); The Prime Minister (1737). Apprentices: Philip Blanchard (1703); Stephen Vauce (1707/8); Joshua Morris (1710); Thomas Browne (1715/16); Richard Haines (1718); William Morris (1718); John Little (1726).
Born Lucan, County Dublin. Married Eleanor, b Maidstone 1796. Chelsea Pensioner
Born Maidstone. Married Dennis, bookseller, musician, Chelsea Pensioner, born Lucan, County Dublin

address.addrLine: St Martins-le-Grand. King's College near Puddledock

org.note: Possibly Roger Vaughan. In partnership with H Lloyd

org.bibl: GEN. Ash Rare Book (Royal Exchange, London) - Catalogue of antique maps for sale (1992)
org.note: Apprenticed to William Rogers. Born in Wales.

address.addrLine: Little Britain. Bishop's Ct in Old Bailey

org.note: Apprentice and successor of THOMAS RODEN.

address.addrLine: Marine Library, Lower Marine Tce (1836). Marine Library, High St (1838)

org.note: Took over from Brown (1836). Transferred to premises of W G Bettison (1838)
traveller with books. Born London. Married Elizabeth, b Bathpool 1805; son b Bathpool 1835
See Archibald VAUCE. Address from Goodall's additional list
Hugenot refugee. Wife Thomas Vautrollier sr; remarried former apprentice to Richard Field; possibly remarried Mr Bounst
Possibly not London; also in Cambridge. Son of Thomas Vautrollier sr

Possibly also London. Huguenot from Edinburgh. Son of London printer. In Cambridge from 1590-1604. In 1590 University gave permission to settle in Cambridge, restricted to selling only foreign-printed books and unbound books. Son Thomas apprenticed to John Legate/Legatt.
Apprenticed to John Legate. Lent money to father in 1600. Son of Manasses Vautrollier. Grandson of Thomas Vautrollier (London, 1562-1587). Nephew of Thomas Vautrollier (London, 1604-1608).

address.addrLine: Res; parish of St Giles, Cripplegate

org.note: Son of Jacqueline & Thomas Vautrollier sr

org.bibl: GEN. Barksdale, A. Beverly, The Printed Note: 500 Years of Music Printing and Engraving (New York: Da Capo Press, 1981), p. 85
org.note: Hugenot refugee. Also in Edinburgh. BroSC 1564. Husb Jaklin; father of Thomas & Manasses. Widow married R Field. Printed Thomas Tallis and William Byrd, Cantiones, quae ab argumento sacrae vocantur, 1575.
Mills passed from Company of White Paper Makers to either D Roussillon or G de Vaux in 1699

address.addrLine: At the Crane in Paul's Chyd (1622). Lit S Door of St Pauls. In Inner Temple nr the Ch (1633-8)

org.note: Part G Emerson. Successor to L Becket's shop 1633; married Becket's widow; stepfather of J Becket. Assoc J Browne
A widow; possibly Mary Vasey, widow of John Vasey

address.addrLine: S/o the Lamb, St Paul's Chyd

org.note: ceased printing by 1566. Also Vele. Freed as Draper (1542). Freed R Ballard as Draper 16/3/1578. BroSC by 1576

address.addrLine: 24 Tabernacle Row. 16 Great Winchester St (1826-7). 26 Great St Helens (1839-52)

org.note: Probably part of firm Dawson & Vear, 51 Threadneedle St. 1824
Successor to Hugh Stratton. Insured his mill in 1789 [Ins pol: S 559549]. Paid excise duties at Uxbridge Collection in 1816
Master of 1 apprentice in 1709. Wife John Veasey

address.addrLine: Head of Elvet Bridge. 74 Fleshergate. 47 Sadler St. 5 Market Pl/ elvet bridge (1834)

org.note: victualler innkeeper. Also in Sunderland. Possibly related to Ralph & Thomas Veitch

org.note: Possibly related to John H & Thomas Veitch
Possibly related to John H & Ralph Veitch
Insured Chesham Mill, Bucks in tenure of George Mowday in 1768
Paid excise duties at Oxford Collection in 1816. [Ref: OXF CRO Land-tax/Assessments. Bod GA OXON b85a(32). PO Directory, OXF, 1854]

address.addrLine: 9 Gt Tower St. 9 Gt Knightrider St. 1 Gt Pulteney St. 17 Queenhithe

org.note: Free StatCo by 1821, MSC (1824-5). Sheriff (1821-2), Lord Mayor of London (1825-6). Trading as Venables & Wilson (1826-30)
Aka Venable. Insured utensils & stock in 1786. Mill insured by William Cook in 1797, William Venable probably his tenant. Paid excise duties at Reading Collection in 1816
Born Roncade, Italy. Pupil of Bartolozzi. Worked in Russia in 1805

address.addrLine: The Vine in Fleet St. Black Bull nr to the three cranes in the Vintry. Bishop's Hall, Stepney &c

org.note: Apprenticed to Henry Carre, Stationer. Ran illegal press nr Bishop's Hall; siezed in 1596

address.addrLine: In Fleet St, o/a the Maidenhead (1585). Res: parish of St Giles, Cripplegate (1587-98)

org.note: Freed as Grocer by J Charlewood; Member Draper Co 1581-5. Not in Stat Co. Pirated `Accidence' (1598) Links to william Barley.

org.note: Son of Rd Venner of Croydon, labourer. Apprenticed to William Morlis. SFIP 454220 (1781/2)
Born Huxham. Married Eliza, b Crediton 1822; ch b Bradninch 1844, Silverton 1835, Exeter 1836-50

Upper end of Old Bailey near Newgate. Angel in Old Bailey. Angel w/o Newgate. Cock in St John St

home- 33 rumford st, chorlton upon medlock
Brazen Serpent in St Paul's Chyd (1581)

org.note: Possibly the same as Thomas Varnam (1711-25)

address.addrLine: 31 Newgate St. Ludgate Hill. 86 Bishopsgate St. St Michael's All. Cornhill. Fore St. 10 Birchin La&c

org.note: Aka Vernon. Trading as Vernor & Chater 1767; Thomas Vernor & Co (1796-86). Succeeded by Vernor & Hood 1794-1806; Vernor, Hood & Sharpe 1806-12. SFIP 386435, 416316, 420304, 423103 & 516664 (1777-86) [IM.EWP8]
See Thomas Vernor & Thomas Hood (Also BROWN)
Sharpe joined Vernor & Hood and took over Hood's affairs when he died in 1811.
See Thomas Vernor. Succeeded by George Cowie & Co

org.bibl: GEN. Guildhall Library MS 14386: Sun Insurance Office Agents' Bond Book 1786-
org.note: Entry in Sun Agents' Bond Book 12.9.1767 & in the Sun Agency Archives' 'record of old agencies' 6.8.1767. Probably same as Arawnah Verral.
Born in Lewes; father of Charles Ebenezer Verral. Probably the same as Verrall
Born in London; son of Charles Verral. Probably the same as Verrall
Part William Lee I (1749-60). Printed `Sussex Weekly Advertiser & Lewes Journal' [See `Sussex County Magazine' vol 15 (1941) pp 247-54] Father of Arawnah Verrall. Constable 1738-58. Aka Verrall
Worked for Samuel Gosnell 1807. Aka Verrall
Edward Verral & William Lee I. Published Sussex Weekly Advertiser' [`Sussex County Magazine' vol 15 (1941) pp 247-54]

constable (79/88/99). Son of Edward Verrall. Published Lewes Journal'. Bondsman for Thomas Cox of Barcombe 1776, Joseph Molineux of Lewes 1777 & John Coppard of Cuckfield 1778. Surveyor of Windows 1765. Aka Verrall

address.addrLine: 8 Prince Albert St & Queen's Rd (51). 98 Queen's Rd (55). 16 Clifton St & 14 Prince Albert St (59)

org.note: Bondsman for John Jenner of Alfriston 1814
Printed `Brief sketch of Alice Davis' (1829); & Peter Brentano's `Perpetual Motion' (1830).
Recusant printer in London; editor, author, propagandist in Paris, Rome & Antwerp. Also Rowlands

org.bibl: GEN. The correspondence of Francis Blomefield (1705-1752), ed. David Stoker, (1992).
org.note: Official engraver to Society of Antiquaries 1717-1756

org.note: Will dated 1/3/1610 proved at York Vol 31/716
Partner in firm of Veysey & Newbery
Dates possibly refer to 2 men (possibly father & son)
Son of John Pope Vibert. Took over business of R D Rodda (1844). Died in Penzance
watchmaker & jeweller. With Tonkin published work by H C Goldsmith (1824). Born & died in Penzance. circulating library 1844
Born Exeter, son of Joseph, dealer in marine stores. Unmarried 1851

Possibly the same as or related to Mary Vickers

Included in Drake's Book of Sheffield and Rotherham.
As George Vidion 1823-6. Printing 1828<. Bro John Mackie Vidion of Maidstone. G Galley previously address
Took over business of Mrs Jane Walker. Bkrpt. Bro George Henry Vidion of Rochester

fishery. Aka Vigus. Printer to Royal Cornwall Geological Society. Succeeded by R D Rodda
master of George Taylor 1765. master of John Sudbury 1772
Agent for the Suffolk Chronicle, Ipswich Express and the Sudbury Free Press. Contributed to the Ipswich Journal 'The Bildeston Boys' and correpondent to the Suffolk Chronicle.
Born Brixham. Married Rebecca, b Exeter 1812; ch b Exeter 1837-47. 1 lodger
Wife George Vincent jr. Assoc John Bainbridge

organist. Proprietor of Viner's Musical Repository. Died in USA. Possibly related to Henry Viner

Mill owner. Mills formerly held by William Fairchild. Bought mills in 1784. Mills sold by Joseph Vowell jr to C Martindale in 1791. Possibly the same as or related to J Vowell jr. Also in London
Mill owner. Bought Borough Mills, Sawston, Cambs in 1784. Possibly the same as or related to J Vowell jr
Mill owner. Possibly the same as or related to Joseph Vowell who bought the mills in 1784. Sold mills to Charles Martindale in 1791
Successor to John Vowell jr. Part William Weare in 1803
Possibly widow John Vowell. Part William Weare 1801-08; trading as Vowell & Weare 1801-8
Sarah Vowell & William Weare. Stationers to East India Company
See J Higgins, H Stokes at these addresses
Partner or employee of Philip Scarlett. In Cambridge from at least 1565. Born Rouen, France.
Paper importer. Surname uncertain. Imported `iij Rymbes albi papiri' in the Christopher in Jan 1554/5
Possibly same as or related to James Vyse of Diss, Norfolk, 1806.
Mill owner? Probably not a paper maker. Insured Boughton Mill in tenure of Margaret Hayes in 1813 (SFIP 882863)
